questions.text: A 20-year-old male fell from the top of a tree and sustained a head injury. He was brought immediately to the emergency department by his family, and on examination, his vitals were stable, with motor weakness present over left limb. On examination of cranial nerves, there is an absence of wrinkling of the forehead and nasolabial folds on the right half of the face along, with diplopia on the right side. What is the clinical diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Millard Gubler syndrome The patient presents with contralateral motor weakness and ipsilateral 6th and 7th nerve palsy. The 7th nerve palsy is of LMN type, as both the right lower and upper part of face are This suggests a pontine injury of the right side of the brain .

Highyeild:

Brainstem syndromes involving PONS- Millard Gubler syndrome Foville syndrome Motor tracts-C/L weakness Motor tracts-C/L weakness 7th nerve palsy-I/L LMN type 7th nerve palsy-I/L LMN type 6th nerve palsy-I/L PPRF(ParaPontine Reticular formation) Diplopia Gaze paralysis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Foville syndrome- presents with parapontine reticular formations (PPRF) involvement, where gaze paralysis is seen. Option: C and D- are midbrain syndromes which will involve the 3rd cranial nerve.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male who had a stroke was brought to the ER by his family. On examination, BP 160/80 mmhg, pulse rate, and respiratory rate are stable. On CNS examination, there is a motor weakness over the left limb along with palsy of right side extra ocular muscles except lateral rectus and superior oblique. The patient also shows some rigidity and hypokinesia. No imaging is done yet. What is the probable diagnosis based on the clinical picture?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PCA lesion The patient has palsy of extraocular muscles on the right side ( Midbrain injury ), motor weakness over the left limb (C/L weakness), some rigidity, and hypokinesia (Parkinsonism features). The clinical picture shown here is of WEBER SYNDROME . Where there is a lesion in ( cerebral peduncle ) in the posterior cerebral artery of the right side, where the cause is found to be hypertension leading to infarction .

Highyeild:

Weber’s syndrome- Cerebral peduncle lesion Posterior cerebral artery infarct 3rd nerve palsy-I/L ophthalmoplegia Motor tracts-C/L weakness Substantia nigra-C/L parkinsonism Corticobulbar tract-C/L UMN 7th nerve palsy C/L 12th nerve palsy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. ACA (Anterior Cerebral Artery) lesion: presents with profound abulia (a delay in verbal and motor response) and bilateral pyramidal signs. with paraparesis or quadriparesis and urinary incontinence. Option: C. Anterior choroidal artery lesion: The complete syndrome of anterior choroidal artery occlusion consists of contralateral hemiplegia , hemianesthesia, and homonymous hemianopia. Option: D. MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) lesion presents with contralateral hemiplegia, hemianesthesia, homonymous hemianopia . Dysarthria is common because of facial weakness. When the dominant hemisphere is involved, global aphasia is present also, and when the nondominant hemisphere is affected, anosognosia and neglect are found.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female came to the neurology OPD with complaints of tremors getting worse on action and visual disturbances. On examination of the patient, it is found that the patient has right 3rd nerve palsy with athetosis and tremors over the left limb. On testing, the patient is also found to have a loss of proprioception over the left side. What is the probable clinical diagnosis of this patient ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Benedikt syndrome The patient has 3rd nerve palsy ( a lesion at midbrain level) with C/L loss of proprioception and has athetosis and tremor . This is a typical feature of Benedikt syndrome.

Highyeild:

Benedikt's syndrome - involves penetrating branch of the PCA (Posterior Cerebral Artery) Tegmental lesion 3rd nerve palsy: I/L ophthalmoplegia Red nucleus-C/L Athetosis,tremor, or chorea Medial lemniscus-C/L loss of proprioception

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Nothnagel's syndrome , will have C/L cerebellar ataxia. Option: C. Weber syndrome , will have a parkinsonism feature. Option: D. Millard Gubler syndrome is a pontine lesion where the cranial nerves involved are VI,VII and not III.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male met with an RTA and was brought to the emergency room. On examination, vitals are stable, and on clinical examination, it is found that the patient has lid retraction and upward gaze paralysis. No motor weakness is noted, and no cranial nerve palsies are noted. What is the probable diagnosis from this clinical picture?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Parinaud syndrome The patient has typical sign -Lid retraction, Upward gaze palsy in absence of motor weakness.

Highyeild:

PARINAUD’S SYNDROME (dorsal midbrain syndrome) This is a distinct supranuclear vertical gaze disorder caused by damage to the posterior commissure. It is a classic sign of hydrocephalus from aqueductal stenosis. Pineal region or midbrain tumours, cysticercosis , and stroke also cause Parinaud’s syndrome. Features include loss of upgaze ( and sometimes downgaze), convergence-retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze, downward ocular deviation (“setting sun” sign), lid retraction (Collier’s sign), skew deviation, pseudo abducens palsy, and light-near dissociation of the pupils.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Benedikt syndrome is excluded as C/L athetosis,tremor, or chorea not mentioned in the question. Option: B. Foville syndrome is a plesion condition where patients will have horizontal gaze palsy and C/L weakness. Option: D. Claude syndrome: It is a combination of Benedikt and Nothnagel syndrome s, where the cranial nerve is affected, while the vertical center is uninvolved and hence excluded.

questions.text: On taking rounds in the ICU, the chief doctor notices a posture in a patient and asks the students, ‘What is the tract likely to be involved here?’ The student examines and notes that there is extension of the upper and lower extremities, with pronation of forearm, flexion of fingers, plantar flexion and abduction. What is the tract likely to be involved and the name of posture?
questions.correct_answer: D. Rubrospinal tract interrupted , decerebrate posture
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rubrospinal tract interrupted , decerebrate posture As the patient’s extension of the upper and lower extremities indicates its decerebrate posturing. In decerebrate posturing, the lesion is below the level of the Red nucleus ; therefore, reticulospinal tract is interrupted, affecting flexion of the arms. Option A,B,C are incorrect.
